newsitem.title: UK: UK wheat harvest rolls towards north, yields good.
newsitem.headline: UK wheat harvest rolls towards north, yields good.

text.p: The British wheat harvest is nearing completion in southern and central regions and yields are generally ample despite an unfavourable spring, consultants and grain buyers said on Thursday.
Farmers had feared severe crop losses in some areas where grains were deprived of moisture at their maturing stage.
Field activity is oftendisrupted by scattered showers but no damage has so far been reported as humidity is low.
Except for light soils where root formation has stayed behind this year, crops generally managed to catch up in the summer just before the harvest.
"We got away with it," said one analyst for agricultural consultancy firm ADAS in East Anglia -- the top growing region.
But milling wheat scored lower than last year on protein levels, and malting barley varieties were generally poor.
Barley harvesting has been completed across the country, except the north and Scotland, and yields were impressive.
Here is a region-by-region update --
EAST ANGLIA
Some 60 to 70 percent of the wheat area is estimated to be harvested in East Anglia. The average yield could still be some 10 percent lower from 1995.
"Yields are all over the place," said one consultant.
But the outturn mproved just before the harvest and yields were generally better than first expected, he added.
On average, milling wheat yields are reported to be around 3.25 tonnes per acre, but losses are partly offset by high bushel weights around 70-80 kilos/hectolitre, grain buyers said.
Milling wheat proteins are just under 11 percent, while those of feed wheat are variable at just about 9.5 percent.
Many farmers have already completed wheat cutting and the rest are likely finish by the end of next week.
The region produced a poor malting barley crop this year with high nitrogen content at around 1.9-2.2 percent and high screenings, but yields were good at some 2.5 kilos per acre.
Despite the drop in quality farmers were confident the brewers would buy their crop. "The trade may well take that material. They may not have any other choice," said one.
Feed barley yields were impressive at 3-3.5 tonnes.
SOUTHEAST
Three quarters of the wheat area has been cut in the Southeast where impressive yields of up to a maximum of five tonnes per acre were reported. Most fell into the 3.5-4 range.
Milling wheat scored modestly on protein at 10.9 percent while feed wheat averaged around 9.8percent, farmers said.
Bushel weights were high around 80 kilos per hectolitre.
Barley harvest is completed and on malting barley, nitrogen contents improved with spring varieties scoring an acceptable 1.6 percent after a poor winter collection, grain buyers said.
EAST MIDLANDS
In East Midlands, about half of the southern wheat area and some 30 percent of the north have been harvested so far.
Feed wheat yields are said to be better than last year with an average of 3.8 tonnes per acre, but milling varieties showed lower protein at around 11 percent.
Farmers are expecting to complete wheat collection within the next week subject to weather conditions.
Barley yields held steady throughout the harvest, while grain size and nitrogen content improved with the spring crop.
SOUTHWEST
Very little wheat has been cut in the Southwest and no early quality assessments were yet available.
But malting barley qualities have improved as the season progressed and yields were reported to be generally good.
YORKSHIRE
Farmers in Yorkshire are just about to finish barley harvesting and move to wheat fields.
Excellent barley yields were reported, averaging three tonnes per acre on feed types, while feed wheat yields were forecast to be an impressive 3.5 tonnes per acre.
Barley showed high specific weights of around 67.2 kilos per hectolitre, farm experts said.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 8072
